More Communication Does Not Result in Smaller Generalization Error in Federated Learning

Romain Chor1, Milad Sefidgaran1, Abdellatif Zaidi12 1Huawei Paris Research Center, France   2Université Gustave Eiffel, France
{romain.chor, milad.sefidgaran2}@huawei.com,  abdellatif.zaidi@univ-eiffel.fr
Abstract

We study the generalization error of statistical learning models in a Federated Learning (FL) setting. Specifically, there are K𝐾K devices or clients, each holding an independent own dataset of size n𝑛n. Individual models, learned locally via Stochastic Gradient Descent, are aggregated (averaged) by a central server into a global model and then sent back to the devices. We consider multiple (say R∈ℕ∗𝑅superscriptℕR\in\mathbb{N}^{*}) rounds of model aggregation and study the effect of R𝑅R on the generalization error of the final aggregated model. We establish an upper bound on the generalization error that accounts explicitly for the effect of R𝑅R (in addition to the number of participating devices K𝐾K and dataset size n𝑛n). It is observed that, for fixed (n,K)𝑛𝐾(n,K), the bound increases with R𝑅R, suggesting that the generalization of such learning algorithms is negatively affected by more frequent communication with the parameter server. Combined with the fact that the empirical risk, however, generally decreases for larger values of R𝑅R, this indicates that R𝑅R might be a parameter to optimize to reduce the population risk of FL algorithms. The results of this paper, which extend straightforwardly to the heterogeneous data setting, are also illustrated through numerical examples.

I Introduction and Problem Setup

Consider the network statistical learning model shown in Figure 1. Also, let some input data Z𝑍Z be distributed according to an unknown distribution μ𝜇\mu over some data space 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}. For example, in supervised learning settings Z≔(X,Y)≔𝑍𝑋𝑌Z\coloneqq(X,Y) where X𝑋X stands for a data sample and Y𝑌Y stands for its associated label. There are K𝐾K devices or clients each equipped with an individual dataset consisting of n𝑛n independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) data points, drawn according to the unknown distribution μ𝜇\mu (the extension of the results that will follow to the heterogeneous, i.e., non i.i.d. setting is straightforward). For instance, every device k∈[K]≔{1,…,K}𝑘delimited-[]𝐾≔1…𝐾k\in[K]\coloneqq\{1,\dots,K\}, has a dataset Sk≔{Zk(1),…,Zk(n)}⊆𝒵n≔subscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘1…superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑛superscript𝒵𝑛S_{k}\coloneqq\{Z_{k}^{(1)},\dots,Z_{k}^{(n)}\}\subseteq\mathcal{Z}^{n}. The devices collaboratively train a (global) model by performing both local computations and updates based on R𝑅R-round, R∈ℕ∗𝑅superscriptℕR\in\mathbb{N}^{*}, interactions with a parameter server. During each round r∈[R]𝑟delimited-[]𝑅r\in[R], local computations at device k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] are performed using the popular Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) algorithm, which applies τ=n/R𝜏𝑛𝑅\tau=n/R updates111For ease of exposition, we assume that R𝑅R divides n𝑛n. of its local model, obtained each by taking one gradient step with respect to a sample from its local data Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k}. Over all rounds, we assume for simplicity that each client performs an epoch over its training dataset i.e., n𝑛n iterations. Specifically, let for r∈[R]𝑟delimited-[]𝑅r\in[R] and t∈[τ]𝑡delimited-[]𝜏t\in[\tau], Wk(r,t)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑟𝑡W_{k}^{(r,t)} denote the individual model of client k𝑘k as obtained after iteration t𝑡t of round r𝑟r. Also, let W¯(r)superscript¯𝑊𝑟\overline{W}^{(r)} denote the model obtained by the parameter server at the end of round r𝑟r, by averaging the individual models of the various devices as obtained during that round, i.e.,

Wk(r,t)=Wk(r,t−1)−ηr,t​∇ℓ​(Zk((r−1)​τ+t),Wk(r,t−1)),superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑟𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑟𝑡1subscript𝜂𝑟𝑡∇ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑟1𝜏𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑟𝑡1W_{k}^{(r,t)}=W_{k}^{(r,t-1)}-\eta_{r,t}\nabla\ell(Z_{k}^{((r-1)\tau+t)},W_{k}^{(r,t-1)}), (3)

where ℓ:𝒵×𝒲→ℝ+:ℓ→𝒵𝒲superscriptℝ\ell:\mathcal{Z}\times\mathcal{W}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{+} is the used loss function (assumed to be identical for all devices) and ηr,t>0subscript𝜂𝑟𝑡0\eta_{r,t}>0 is the learning rate at iteration t𝑡t of round r𝑟r. For simplicity, learning rates are assumed to be identical across all devices. Also, in the first round, prior to performing any computation all models are set to some data-independent values.

The algorithm described here is a multi-round distributed SGD for Federated Learning (FL), which we denote hereafter in short as FL-SGD and we use interchangeably the shorthand notations 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} and FL-SGD to refer to it, i.e., 𝒜=FL-SGD𝒜FL-SGD\mathcal{A}=\text{FL-SGD}. Its output hypothesis is the final aggregated model once the R𝑅R rounds are completed, i.e., W¯=W¯(R)¯𝑊superscript¯𝑊𝑅\overline{W}=\overline{W}^{(R)}; and it can be computed using the recursion equations (1), (2) and (3).

The empirical risk on dataset s={s1,…,sK}∈𝒵n​K𝑠subscript𝑠1…subscript𝑠𝐾superscript𝒵𝑛𝐾s=\{s_{1},\ldots,s_{K}\}\in\mathcal{Z}^{nK} of a particular hypothesis w¯=𝒜​(s)¯𝑤𝒜𝑠\overline{w}=\mathcal{A}(s) is evaluated as the average, over all devices, of its empirical risk for each of them, computed for all used data samples during all rounds, i.e.,

ℒ^​(s,w¯)=1n​K​∑k=1K∑r=1R∑t=1τℓ​(zk((r−1)​τ+t),w¯).^ℒ𝑠¯𝑤1𝑛𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝜏ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑘𝑟1𝜏𝑡¯𝑤\hat{\mathcal{L}}(s,\overline{w})=\frac{1}{nK}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{r=1}^{R}\sum_{t=1}^{\tau}\ell(z_{k}^{((r-1)\tau+t)},\overline{w}).\vspace{-0.1cm} (4)

Similarly, the population risk for hypothesis w¯¯𝑤\overline{w} is given as ℒ​(w¯)=𝔼Z∼μ​[ℓ​(Z,w¯)]ℒ¯𝑤subscript𝔼similar-to𝑍𝜇delimited-[]ℓ𝑍¯𝑤\mathcal{L}(\overline{w})=\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim\mu}[\ell(Z,\overline{w})]; and the generalization error for dataset s={s1,…,sK}∈𝒵n​K𝑠subscript𝑠1…subscript𝑠𝐾superscript𝒵𝑛𝐾s=\{s_{1},\ldots,s_{K}\}\in\mathcal{Z}^{nK} and hypothesis w¯=𝒜​(s)¯𝑤𝒜𝑠\overline{w}=\mathcal{A}(s) is evaluated as

gen​(s,w¯)=ℒ​(w¯)−ℒ^​(s,w¯).gen𝑠¯𝑤ℒ¯𝑤^ℒ𝑠¯𝑤{\text{gen}}(s,\overline{w})=\mathcal{L}(\overline{w})-\hat{\mathcal{L}}(s,\overline{w}). (5)

The expected generalization error, over all possible datasets S={S1,…,SK}∈𝒵n​K𝑆subscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝐾superscript𝒵𝑛𝐾S=\{S_{1},\ldots,S_{K}\}\in\mathcal{Z}^{nK}, is defined as

𝔼S∼μ⊗n​K​[gen​(S,𝒜​(S))]=𝔼S∼μ⊗n​K​[ℒ​(𝒜​(S))−ℒ^​(S,𝒜​(S))].subscript𝔼similar-to𝑆superscript𝜇tensor-productabsent𝑛𝐾delimited-[]gen𝑆𝒜𝑆subscript𝔼similar-to𝑆superscript𝜇tensor-productabsent𝑛𝐾delimited-[]ℒ𝒜𝑆^ℒ𝑆𝒜𝑆\mathbb{E}_{S\sim\mu^{\otimes nK}}[{\text{gen}}(S,\mathcal{A}(S))]=\mathbb{E}_{S\sim\mu^{\otimes nK}}\big{[}\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{A}(S))-\hat{\mathcal{L}}(S,\mathcal{A}(S))\big{]}. (6)

where the expectation in (6) is defined also w.r.t. any other possible stochasticity in the learning algorithm.

In this paper we are interested in studying the generalization error of 𝒜=FL-SGD𝒜FL-SGD\mathcal{A}=\text{FL-SGD}. In particular, we ask the question:

How does the expected generalization error as defined by (6) evolve with the number of rounds R𝑅R?

Such question received so far only partial answer. For example, it was shown theoretically [1, 2, 3], and also observed experimentally therein, that in FL-type algorithms the empirical risk decreases with the number of rounds. However, to the best of our knowledge, no work has studied this behavior for the generalization error. One central mathematical difficulty in studying the behavior of the expected generalization error as defined by (6) lies in that common tools that are generally applied in similar settings, such as the Leave-one-out Expansion Lemma of [4], do not apply easily when the empirical risk is defined as in (4) (and, so, the generalization error as in (6)). In particular, as it will become clearer throughout when the empirical risk is evaluated as given by (4) the initialization step (2) induces statistical correlations among the devices models’ which become stronger with R𝑅R and are not easy to handle. For example, observe that in the analysis of the contribution of a particular model Wk(r,t)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑟𝑡W_{k}^{(r,t)} to the overall expected generalization error of the global hypothesis W¯¯𝑊\overline{W} as defined by (6), one has to account for the dependence of Wk(r,t)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑟𝑡W_{k}^{(r,t)} on other devices’ samples Zk′(r′​τ+t)superscriptsubscript𝑍superscript𝑘′superscript𝑟′𝜏𝑡Z_{k^{\prime}}^{(r^{\prime}\tau+t)} for every k′≠ksuperscript𝑘′𝑘k^{\prime}\neq k, r′<rsuperscript𝑟′𝑟r^{\prime}<r and t∈[τ]𝑡delimited-[]𝜏t\in[\tau]. (See Figure 2). Perhaps this explains why while the behavior of (6) was studied in a few works [5, 6, 7, 8] for the particular case of R=1𝑅1R=1 (sometimes referred to as “one-shot" FL), much lesser is known in the case of multi-round FL – see Section I-B Related Works for few recent works on this, in some of which the mentioned correlations are sometimes eluded by defining the empirical risk differently.

I-A Main Contributions

As we already mentioned, in this paper we study the expected generalization error as defined by (6). We focus on the case in which the loss function ℓ​(⋅,⋅)ℓ⋅⋅\ell(\cdot,\cdot) can be expressed as a Bregman divergence [9]. This encompasses a large family of loss functions, including the squared Euclidean distance commonly used in regression problems. We establish an upper bound on the generalization error (6) that accounts explicitly for the number of rounds R𝑅R. Essentially, the proof techniques involve bounding steps that account judiciously for the statistical correlations induced by (2) and which build up through the rounds. Furthermore, by studying its evolution with the number of rounds R𝑅R we observe that, for fixed (n,K)𝑛𝐾(n,K), the established bound can increase with R𝑅R, suggesting that the generalization of FL-SGD is negatively affected by more frequent communication with the parameter server. Combined with known results about that the empirical risk, however, generally decreases for larger values of R𝑅R, this indicates that R𝑅R might be a parameter to optimize in order to reduce the population risk of FL-SGD algorithms. These results, which for simplicity are established here for the i.i.d. data setting and extend easily to the heterogeneous (non i.i.d.) setting, are also illustrated through some numerical examples in which the bound is compared to the true (measured) generalization error.

It is noteworthy that the results of this paper extend easily to the case of aperiodic communication with the parameter server and/or more general aggregated models W¯(r)superscript¯𝑊𝑟\overline{W}^{(r)}, such as any arbitrary deterministic function of the local models {Wk(r,τ)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑟𝜏𝑘1𝐾\{W_{k}^{(r,\tau)}\}_{k=1}^{K} among which the arithmetic average (1) that we consider here is a common choice [10]. Finally, the analysis also carries over easily for settings in which local model updates also account for additional stochasticity through added noise in the gradient steps, i.e., when (3) is substituted by the more general

Wk(r,t)=Wk(r,t−1)−ηr,t​∇ℓ​(Zk((r−1)​τ+t),Wk(r,t−1))+ξt,superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑟𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑟𝑡1subscript𝜂𝑟𝑡∇ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑟1𝜏𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑟𝑡1subscript𝜉𝑡W_{k}^{(r,t)}=W_{k}^{(r,t-1)}-\eta_{r,t}\nabla\ell(Z_{k}^{((r-1)\tau+t)},W_{k}^{(r,t-1)})+\xi_{t},\vspace{-0.1cm}

where ξtsubscript𝜉𝑡\xi_{t} stands for some added random noise.

I-B Related Works

A major focus of machine learning research over recent years has been the study of statistical learning algorithms when applied to data generated and processed in a distributed (network or graph) manner [10, 11, 12]. Such setups are of prime importance, especially when some degree of privacy is required [13, 14, 15, 16] and/or computational power is limited [17, 16]. The study of the behavior of the generalization error, a problem which is understood only very partially even in centralized learning settings, is even more challenging in the case of distributed and multi-round algorithms such as the popular FL [10]. In particular, while a few works [1, 2] have already demonstrated that multi-round communication generally yields smaller empirical risk, only very little is known about the effect of the number of communication rounds on the generalization error. For the special case of one-round communication, sometimes referred to as “distributed learning" or “one-shot" FL, bounds on the generalization error that improve upon the corresponding ones for the centralized setting with, essentially a factor of 1/K1𝐾1/\sqrt{K}, are established in [8] for linear and location models and losses that can be expressed as Bregman divergence; and in [6] and [5] for a broader class of loss functions, using information-theoretic and rate-distortion theoretic approaches.

Compared with the multi-round setup that we study here, the one-round setup suffers from the lack of a joint optimization guarantee, i.e., it may not be possible to make the empirical risk arbitrarily small. From a theoretical angle, however, the study of the generalization error in this latter case is less difficult comparatively, as there are no statistical couplings among the devices’ models by the memoryless assumption on the dataset. Most relevant to the problem that we study in this paper is the recent work [8]. In [8], the authors study a quantity, which they argue as being a proxy to the true generalization error as defined by (6), given as

ΔSGD​(s)=subscriptΔSGD𝑠absent\displaystyle\Delta_{\text{SGD}}(s)= (7)
1R​∑r=1R(ℒ​(w¯(r))−1τ​K​∑k=1K∑t=1τℓ​(zk((r−1)​τ+t),w¯(r))).1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑅ℒsuperscript¯𝑤𝑟1𝜏𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝜏ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑘𝑟1𝜏𝑡superscript¯𝑤𝑟\displaystyle\quad\frac{1}{R}\sum_{r=1}^{R}\left(\mathcal{L}(\overline{w}^{(r)})-\frac{1}{\tau K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{t=1}^{\tau}\ell(z_{k}^{((r-1)\tau+t)},\overline{w}^{(r)})\right).

As the authors mention, this quantity is considered therein mainly for simplicity and in order to avoid accounting for the dependence of Wk(r,t)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑟𝑡W_{k}^{(r,t)} on other devices’ samples Zk′(r′​τ+t)superscriptsubscript𝑍superscript𝑘′superscript𝑟′𝜏𝑡Z_{k^{\prime}}^{(r^{\prime}\tau+t)} for every k′≠ksuperscript𝑘′𝑘k^{\prime}\neq k, r′<rsuperscript𝑟′𝑟r^{\prime}<r and t∈[τ]𝑡delimited-[]𝜏t\in[\tau]. In a sense, this reduces the problem to a virtual one-round setup; but at the expense of analyzing the alternate quantity (7) in place of the true generalization error (6) that we study in this paper.

I-C Notations and Organization of the Paper

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Some technical complements are given in Section II-A. Then, Section II-B presents an upper bound on the expected generalization error of a model learned in the FL setup considered in this paper. The effect of communication on the generalization error of FL algorithms and what insights our bound give on that effect are discussed in Section II-C. This is illustrated through simulations, which are provided in Section III. Finally, our result’s proof is given in section IV.

Random variables, their realizations, and their domains are denoted respectively by upper-case, lower-case, and calligraphy fonts, e.g., X𝑋X, x𝑥x, and 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}. Their distributions and expectations are denoted by PXsubscript𝑃𝑋P_{X} and 𝔼​[X]𝔼delimited-[]𝑋\mathbb{E}[X]. For two random variables X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y, PX|Ysubscript𝑃conditional𝑋𝑌P_{X|Y} denotes the conditional distribution of X𝑋X given Y𝑌Y. 𝒵,𝒲𝒵𝒲\mathcal{Z},~{}\mathcal{W} are subsets of ℝd,d≥1superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑1\mathbb{R}^{d},~{}d\geq 1. ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| denotes the standard Euclidean norm in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. For a,b∈ℕ𝑎𝑏ℕa,b\in\mathbb{N}, [a;b]𝑎𝑏[a;b] denotes the set of integers between a𝑎a and b𝑏b. The set of integers from 1 to n∈ℕ∗𝑛superscriptℕn\in\mathbb{N}^{*} is denoted by [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n]. Other specific notations are introduced throughout the paper, whenever they are used.

II Main Results

In this section we establish the main result of this paper, which is an upper bound on the expected generalization error of the studied FL-SGD as given by (6); and we study its evolution with R𝑅R.

II-A Assumptions and Some Preliminaries

As already mentioned we focus on the case in which the loss function ℓ​(⋅,⋅)ℓ⋅⋅\ell(\cdot,\cdot) is expressed as a Bregman divergence [9], which includes a large family of losses such as the squared error distance used extensively in regression problems (see [18] for more examples of such loss functions). Recall that for a continuously differentiable and strictly convex function F:ℝd→ℝ:𝐹→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝF:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}, the associated Bregman divergence between two vectors w,z∈ℝd𝑤𝑧superscriptℝ𝑑w,z\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is defined as

DF​(w,z)≔F​(w)−F​(z)−⟨∇F​(z),w−z⟩.≔subscript𝐷𝐹𝑤𝑧𝐹𝑤𝐹𝑧∇𝐹𝑧𝑤𝑧D_{F}(w,z)\coloneqq F(w)-F(z)-\langle\nabla F(z),w-z\rangle.\vspace{-0.1cm}

where ⟨⋅,⋅⟩⋅⋅\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle is the usual inner product.

In the results that will follow we will often make use of one or both following assumptions.

Assumption 1

Let F:ℝd→ℝ:𝐹→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝF:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} be a continuously differentiable and strictly convex function. The loss function ℓ:𝒵×𝒲→ℝ+:ℓ→𝒵𝒲superscriptℝ\ell:\mathcal{Z}\times\mathcal{W}\to\mathbb{R}^{+} is the Bregman divergence associated to F𝐹F i.e., ∀z,w∈𝒵×𝒲for-all𝑧𝑤𝒵𝒲\forall\>z,w\in\mathcal{Z}\times\mathcal{W} we have ℓ​(z,w)=DF​(w,z)ℓ𝑧𝑤subscript𝐷𝐹𝑤𝑧\ell(z,w)=D_{F}(w,z).

Assumption 2

The function F𝐹F defining the Bregman divergence DFsubscript𝐷𝐹D_{F} is L𝐿L-smooth for some L>0𝐿0L>0 i.e., ∀w,w′∈𝒲for-all𝑤superscript𝑤′𝒲\forall\>w,w^{\prime}\in\mathcal{W} we have ‖∇F​(w)−∇F​(w′)‖≤L​‖w−w′‖norm∇𝐹𝑤∇𝐹superscript𝑤′𝐿norm𝑤superscript𝑤′\|\nabla F(w)-\nabla F(w^{\prime})\|\leq L\|w-w^{\prime}\|.

In the proof of our upper bound on the expected generalization error (6) that will follow, we make extensive use of the so-called Leave-one-out Lemma [4, Lemma 11], a result which essentially relates the generalization error of a learning algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} to its “average stability" to the replacement of a sample in its training dataset D≔{Z(1),…,Z(m)}⊆𝒵m≔𝐷superscript𝑍1…superscript𝑍𝑚superscript𝒵𝑚D\coloneqq\{Z^{(1)},\ldots,Z^{(m)}\}\subseteq\mathcal{Z}^{m} by an i.i.d. copy of it, i.e., the average difference between losses obtained using a model trained using ℬℬ\mathcal{B} on D𝐷D and one that is obtained using a model trained using ℬℬ\mathcal{B} on an i.i.d. dataset D~≔{Z~(1),…,Z~(m)}⊆𝒵m≔~𝐷superscript~𝑍1…superscript~𝑍𝑚superscript𝒵𝑚\tilde{D}\coloneqq\{\tilde{Z}^{(1)},\ldots,\tilde{Z}^{(m)}\}\subseteq\mathcal{Z}^{m}, where for each i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], Z~(i)superscript~𝑍𝑖\tilde{Z}^{(i)} is an i.i.d. copy of Z(i)∼μsimilar-tosuperscript𝑍𝑖𝜇Z^{(i)}\sim\mu.

Lemma 1 (Leave-one-out (Expansion) Lemma[4, Lemma 11])

Let D(i)≔{Z(1),…,Z~(i),…,Z(m)}≔superscript𝐷𝑖superscript𝑍1…superscript~𝑍𝑖…superscript𝑍𝑚D^{(i)}\coloneqq\{Z^{(1)},\ldots,\tilde{Z}^{(i)},\ldots,Z^{(m)}\} be a version of D={Z(1),…,Z(i),…,Z(m)}𝐷superscript𝑍1…superscript𝑍𝑖…superscript𝑍𝑚D=\{Z^{(1)},\ldots,Z^{(i)},\ldots,Z^{(m)}\} in which the element Z(i)superscript𝑍𝑖Z^{(i)} is replaced by an i.i.d. copy of it Z~(i)superscript~𝑍𝑖\tilde{Z}^{(i)}. Also, denote D~={Z~(1),…,Z~(m)}~𝐷superscript~𝑍1…superscript~𝑍𝑚\tilde{D}=\{\tilde{Z}^{(1)},\ldots,\tilde{Z}^{(m)}\}. Then, it holds that

𝔼D∼μ⊗m​[gen​(D,ℬ​(D))]subscript𝔼similar-to𝐷superscript𝜇tensor-productabsent𝑚delimited-[]gen𝐷ℬ𝐷\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{D\sim\mu^{\otimes m}}[{\text{gen}}(D,\mathcal{B}(D))]
=1m​∑i=1m𝔼D,D~​[ℓ​(Z~(i),ℬ​(D))−ℓ​(Z~(i),ℬ​(D(i)))].absent1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝔼𝐷~𝐷delimited-[]ℓsuperscript~𝑍𝑖ℬ𝐷ℓsuperscript~𝑍𝑖ℬsuperscript𝐷𝑖\displaystyle\quad=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\mathbb{E}_{D,\tilde{D}}\big{[}\ell(\tilde{Z}^{(i)},\mathcal{B}(D))-\ell(\tilde{Z}^{(i)},\mathcal{B}(D^{(i)}))\big{]}. (8)

II-B Upper Bound on the Expected Generalization Error

Let for every k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] and i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], Sk(i)superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘𝑖S_{k}^{(i)} designate a copy of the dataset Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} of device k𝑘k in which Zk(i)superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑖Z_{k}^{(i)} is replaced with an i.i.d. copy of it Z~k(i)superscriptsubscript~𝑍𝑘𝑖\tilde{Z}_{k}^{(i)}. That is, Sk(i)≔(Sk∖{Zk(i)})∪{Z~k(i)}≔superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘𝑖subscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript~𝑍𝑘𝑖S_{k}^{(i)}\coloneqq(S_{k}\setminus\{Z_{k}^{(i)}\})\cup\{\tilde{Z}_{k}^{(i)}\}. Similarly, for every i∈Ir𝑖subscript𝐼𝑟i\in I_{r} define Sk,r(i)≔(Sk,r∖Zk(i))∪Z~k(i)≔superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘𝑟𝑖subscript𝑆𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript~𝑍𝑘𝑖S_{k,r}^{(i)}\coloneqq(S_{k,r}\setminus Z_{k}^{(i)})\cup\tilde{Z}_{k}^{(i)}. Also, we use the shorthand notation S1:K,r≔∪k=1KSk,r≔subscript𝑆:1𝐾𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑘𝑟S_{1:K,r}\coloneqq\cup_{k=1}^{K}S_{k,r}.

Now, recall the FL-SGD algorithm studied in this paper and described in Section I, whose output hypothesis is W¯=W¯(R)¯𝑊superscript¯𝑊𝑅\overline{W}=\overline{W}^{(R)} as can be computed using (1), (2) and (3). The analysis of the associated expected generalization error as defined by (6), however, is not easy. One important difficulty is as follows: for every k′≠ksuperscript𝑘′𝑘k^{\prime}\neq k, r′<rsuperscript𝑟′𝑟r^{\prime}<r and t∈[τ]𝑡delimited-[]𝜏t\in[\tau], a change of one sample in Sk′,r′subscript𝑆superscript𝑘′superscript𝑟′S_{k^{\prime},r^{\prime}} implies a change of the model Wk′(r′,t)subscriptsuperscript𝑊superscript𝑟′𝑡superscript𝑘′W^{(r^{\prime},t)}_{k^{\prime}} of device k′superscript𝑘′k^{\prime}; and, in turn, of the (intermediate) aggregated model W¯(r′)superscript¯𝑊superscript𝑟′\overline{W}^{(r^{\prime})} and all subsequent ones W¯(r~)superscript¯𝑊~𝑟\overline{W}^{(\tilde{r})} for r′<r~≤Rsuperscript𝑟′~𝑟𝑅r^{\prime}<\tilde{r}\leq R. In particular, this changes Wk(r,t)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑟𝑡W_{k}^{(r,t)} for all t∈[τ]𝑡delimited-[]𝜏t\in[\tau]. (See Figure 2 for an example with K=2𝐾2K=2 and R=2𝑅2R=2). These induced statistical correlations then arise naturally when one applies Lemma 1, which thus becomes less amenable to easy computations.

The next theorem states the main result of this paper, which is an upper bound on the expected generalization error (6) of W¯¯𝑊\overline{W}.

The proof of Theorem 1 is given in Section IV. ∎

We now pause to discuss the result of the theorem. The RHS of (1) may appear as somewhat not amenable to an easy interpretation at first glance. A closer investigation, however, reveals that it is not. In particular, one utility of the result is that it somewhat decouples the aforementioned statistical correlations. Indeed, the first sum term of the RHS of (1) is an average over all devices and rounds of the expected generalization error of a (centralized) modified SGD applied at round r𝑟r by device k𝑘k on the part Sk,rsubscript𝑆𝑘𝑟S_{k,r} of its local dataset Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k}. The modification is in that while the gradient steps are all computed only w.r.t. to samples of Sk,rsubscript𝑆𝑘𝑟S_{k,r} the model learned by this modified SGD is an average (over all parts Sk′,r′subscript𝑆superscript𝑘′superscript𝑟′S_{k^{\prime},r^{\prime}} of all devices and all rounds prior to round r𝑟r), i.e., the term inside the first sum of the RHS of (1) is

𝔼Sk,r​[gen​(Sk,r,𝔼S1:K,r′<r​[SGD​(W¯(r−1),Sk,r)])].subscript𝔼subscript𝑆𝑘𝑟delimited-[]gensubscript𝑆𝑘𝑟subscript𝔼subscript𝑆:1𝐾superscript𝑟′𝑟delimited-[]SGDsuperscript¯𝑊𝑟1subscript𝑆𝑘𝑟\mathbb{E}_{S_{k,r}}\left[\text{gen}\left(S_{k,r},\mathbb{E}_{S_{1:K},r^{\prime}<r}\big{[}\text{SGD}(\overline{W}^{(r-1)},S_{k,r})\big{]}\right)\right]. (10)

Equivalently, recalling that SGD iterates essentially consist of an initialization term added to an innovation term obtained by application of the gradient of the loss function on a new sample, for every pair (k,r)∈[K]×[R]𝑘𝑟delimited-[]𝐾delimited-[]𝑅(k,r)\in[K]\times[R], (10) captures the statistical correlations caused by the local models’ innovation parts till round r𝑟r. Similarly, for every (k,r)∈[K]×[R−1]𝑘𝑟delimited-[]𝐾delimited-[]𝑅1(k,r)\in[K]\times[R-1] the second sum term of the RHS of  (1) captures the statistical correlations caused by the local models’ innovation parts from round (r+1)𝑟1(r+1) to R𝑅R. It is noteworthy that these correlations are eluded if instead of the true generalization error (6) one considers the proxy (7) of [8], a setting for which the second term of the RHS of (1) vanishes.

The following corollary is an easy consequence of Theorem 1.

Corollary 1

For “one-shot" FL-SGD, i.e., R=1𝑅1R=1, if the loss ℓ​(⋅,⋅)ℓ⋅⋅\ell(\cdot,\cdot) satisfies the condition of Assumption 1, then

𝔼S​[gen⁡(S,W¯(1))]=1K2​∑k=1K𝔼Sk​[gen⁡(Sk,Wk(1,τ))].subscript𝔼𝑆delimited-[]gen𝑆superscript¯𝑊11superscript𝐾2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝔼subscript𝑆𝑘delimited-[]gensubscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘1𝜏\mathbb{E}_{S}\left[\operatorname{gen}(S,\overline{W}^{(1)})\right]=\frac{1}{K^{2}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}_{S_{k}}\left[\operatorname{gen}(S_{k},W_{k}^{(1,\tau)})\right].\vspace{-0.1cm} (11)
Proof:

Observe that in the proof of Theorem 1 in Section IV, in this case (R=1𝑅1R=1) the second term of (19) is zero. The rest of the proof follows by substituting τ=n𝜏𝑛\tau=n and applying Lemma 3. ∎

It is interesting to observe that in (11) the expected generalization error decays with the number of clients K𝐾K faster than the average (over clients) of their individual expected generalization errors defined w.r.t. to only their own datasets. The convergence boost is of the order of 1/K1𝐾1/K.

II-C Effect of Communication Rounds R𝑅R

For simplicity we assume identical learning rates, i.e., ηr,t=η,∀(r,t)∈[R]×[τ]formulae-sequencesubscript𝜂𝑟𝑡𝜂for-all𝑟𝑡delimited-[]𝑅delimited-[]𝜏\eta_{r,t}=\eta,~{}\forall(r,t)\in[R]\times[\tau]. Previous works [19, 20, 21] have shown that SGD with n𝑛n iterations on mini-batches of size b𝑏b, and with learning rate η𝜂\eta, has an expected generalization error that (roughly) evolves as 𝒪​(f​(b/η)/n)𝒪𝑓𝑏𝜂𝑛\mathcal{O}(f(b/\eta)/\sqrt{n}), where f​(b/η)𝑓𝑏𝜂f(b/\eta) is a function that captures the dependency on the mini-batch size and learning rate. Moreover, several works [22, 23] have reported that the function f​(⋅)𝑓⋅f(\cdot) increases with increasing values of the ratio b/η𝑏𝜂b/\eta. Hereafter, in particular, we investigate two extreme cases, R=1𝑅1R=1 and R=n𝑅𝑛R=n – see the next section for results with other, intermediate, values of R𝑅R.

For R=1𝑅1R=1, the setup reduces to one-shot FL [17] in which the local models are all trained in n𝑛n iterations and aggregated once. In this case, by application of Corollary 1 (see also [8]), we get

𝔼​[gen⁡(S,W¯(1))]𝔼delimited-[]gen𝑆superscript¯𝑊1\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{gen}(S,\overline{W}^{(1)})] =𝒪​(1K​𝔼​[gen⁡(S1,W1(1,n))])absent𝒪1𝐾𝔼delimited-[]gensubscript𝑆1superscriptsubscript𝑊11𝑛\displaystyle=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{K}\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{gen}(S_{1},W_{1}^{(1,n)})]\right)
=𝒪​(f​(1/η)/n​K2).absent𝒪𝑓1𝜂𝑛superscript𝐾2\displaystyle=\mathcal{O}(f(1/\eta)/\sqrt{nK^{2}}).\vspace{-0.1cm}

For the case R=n𝑅𝑛R=n, the models are aggregated after each local iteration. Thus, the expected generalization error coincides with that of SGD with mini-batch of size b=K𝑏𝐾b=K and learning rate η𝜂\eta. A bound on the generalization error in this case then behaves, roughly, as 𝒪​(f​(K/η)/n​K)𝒪𝑓𝐾𝜂𝑛𝐾\mathcal{O}(f(K/\eta)/\sqrt{nK}). Since f​(⋅)𝑓⋅f(\cdot) is an increasing function as observed, e.g., in  [22, 23], in particular, this means that for the FL-SGD that we study in this paper the expected generalization error (6) increases with the number of rounds R𝑅R. This is in line with the findings of [8] and [5] (see also [6]) which have established bounds on the generalization error of a distributed setting that are smaller than the corresponding one of the centralized learning. This, combined with the intuition that more communication generally induces further “homogeneity" among the individual devices’ models, which then account better for variations in each local dataset, is in accordance with our observation here that (6) increases with R𝑅R.

The result of Theorem 1 also reflects this evolution with R𝑅R. Indeed, the first term of (1) computed for R=n𝑅𝑛R=n seems to be larger than the corresponding one for R=1𝑅1R=1. Moreover, it is easily seen that for R=1𝑅1R=1 the second term of (1) equals zero whereas it is positive for R=n𝑅𝑛R=n. The observation that (6) increases with R𝑅R is also illustrated numerically through experiments in the next section.

III Experimental results

We consider the ordinary least squares (OLS) regression problem. Precisely, the loss function is the squared Euclidean distance i.e., ∀z≔(x,y)∈ℝd×ℝ,∀w∈ℝd:ℓ(z,w)=(wtx−y)2\forall z\coloneqq(x,y)\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R},\forall w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\colon\ell(z,w)=(w^{t}x-y)^{2}, which is a Bregman divergence DFsubscript𝐷𝐹D_{F} for F:y↦y2:𝐹maps-to𝑦superscript𝑦2F:y\mapsto y^{2}. In our experiments, for a dataset S𝑆S of size n​K𝑛𝐾nK, we measure the expected generalization error (6) experimentally, compare it to the result of our upper bound of Theorem 1, and depict the evolution of both of them as functions of the number of rounds R𝑅R.

Each of the K𝐾K clients is equipped with a subset of S𝑆S of size n𝑛n. We implement FL-SGD on a single machine. We train models w¯(R)superscript¯𝑤𝑅\overline{w}^{(R)} in that setup for various values of the number of communication rounds R𝑅R. The population risk 𝔼Z​[ℓ​(Z,w¯(R))]subscript𝔼𝑍delimited-[]ℓ𝑍superscript¯𝑤𝑅\mathbb{E}_{Z}[\ell(Z,\overline{w}^{(R)})] is estimated by the risk calculated over a test dataset of size Nt​e​s​t=103subscript𝑁𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡superscript103N_{test}=10^{3}. The expectations that are involved in Theorem 1 are approximated by Monte-Carlo simulations for M=103𝑀superscript103M=10^{3}. For more details on the experiments, the reader may refer to Appendix B.

The results shown in Figure 3 are obtained with the following numerical values: d=10𝑑10d=10 (number of features), n=500𝑛500n=500 and K=10𝐾10K=10. As visible from the figure, the bound of Theorem 1 captures the increasing behavior of the true (measured) generalization error with R𝑅R. Combined with the known observation that the empirical risk, however, generally decreases for larger values of R𝑅R (a fact that is also observed in our experiments), this indicates that R𝑅R might be a parameter to optimize in order to reduce the population risk of FL-SGD. The observed gap between the bound (which is tight for large n𝑛n) and the true values of the generalization error is an indicator that the latter decays faster than 1/n1𝑛1/n for small values of n𝑛n.

    S(k,i)≔(S∖{Zk(i)})∪{Z~k(i)}≔superscript𝑆𝑘𝑖𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript~𝑍𝑘𝑖S^{(k,i)}\coloneqq(S\setminus\{Z_{k}^{(i)}\})\cup\{\tilde{Z}_{k}^{(i)}\} and Sk(i)≔(Sk∖{Zk(i)})∪{Z~k(i)}≔superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘𝑖subscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript~𝑍𝑘𝑖S_{k}^{(i)}\coloneqq(S_{k}\setminus\{Z_{k}^{(i)}\})\cup\{\tilde{Z}_{k}^{(i)}\}.

  • (ii)

    ∀t∈[n]for-all𝑡delimited-[]𝑛\forall t\in[n], Zk∖i(t)superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑖𝑡Z_{k\setminus i}^{(t)} denotes Z~k(i)superscriptsubscript~𝑍𝑘𝑖\tilde{Z}_{k}^{(i)} if t=i𝑡𝑖t=i, and Zk(t)superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑡Z_{k}^{(t)} otherwise. Similarly, Zj∖k,i(t)=Zj(t)superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑗𝑘𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑗𝑡Z_{j\setminus k,i}^{(t)}=Z_{j}^{(t)} if j≠k𝑗𝑘j\neq k, and Zj∖k,i(t)=Zk∖i(t)superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑗𝑘𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑖𝑡Z_{j\setminus k,i}^{(t)}=Z_{k\setminus i}^{(t)} if j=k𝑗𝑘j=k.     W¯∖k,i(r)≔1K​∑j=1KWj∖k,i(r,τ)≔superscriptsubscript¯𝑊𝑘𝑖𝑟1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑗𝑘𝑖𝑟𝜏\overline{W}_{\setminus k,i}^{(r)}\coloneqq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{j=1}^{K}W_{j\setminus k,i}^{(r,\tau)}, where Wj∖k,i(r,τ)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑗𝑘𝑖𝑟𝜏W_{j\setminus k,i}^{(r,\tau)} is the j𝑗j-th client’s model at of iteration τ𝜏\tau of round r𝑟r and iteration τ𝜏\tau when the k𝑘k-th client’s model Wk∖i(r,τ)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑖𝑟𝜏W_{k\setminus i}^{(r,\tau)} is obtained using the dataset Sk(i)superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘𝑖S_{k}^{(i)}.

  • (iv)

    For every u𝑢u, let the following denotes the SGD “innovations" during round q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2

Finally, throughout we let S′≔{Z~k(i):k∈[K],i∈[n]}≔superscript𝑆′conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript~𝑍𝑘𝑖formulae-sequence𝑘delimited-[]𝐾𝑖delimited-[]𝑛S^{\prime}\coloneqq\{\tilde{Z}_{k}^{(i)}\colon k\in[K],i\in[n]\}.

In what follows, for convenience we first provide the proof for the specific case of R=2𝑅2R=2; and then extend it to general R𝑅R. The proofs of some lemmas, used hereafter, are deferred to Appendix A.

IV-A Case R=2𝑅2R=2

First, we state the following lemma which allows to decompose the expected generalization error into two terms that we analyze separately.

Recall that for k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K], the dataset Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} is partitioned (in this case) into two subsets of equal size τ=n/2𝜏𝑛2\tau=n/2: Sk,1subscript𝑆𝑘1S_{k,1} and Sk,2subscript𝑆𝑘2S_{k,2}, respectively used during the first round and second round. First note that Lemma 2 and its proof can be generalized easily to arbitrary R≥2𝑅2R\geq 2. That is, under Assumption 1,

\IEEEeqnarraymulticol​3​l​𝔼S​[gen⁡(S,W¯(R))]\IEEEeqnarraymulticol3𝑙subscript𝔼𝑆delimited-[]gen𝑆superscript¯𝑊𝑅\displaystyle\IEEEeqnarraymulticol{3}{l}{\mathbb{E}_{S}[\operatorname{gen}(S,\overline{W}^{(R)})]}
=\displaystyle= 1n​K2​∑i,k𝔼S,S′​[⟨gk(i),Wk∖i(1,τ)−Wk(1,τ)⟩]1𝑛superscript𝐾2subscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝔼𝑆superscript𝑆′delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑖1𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘1𝜏\displaystyle\frac{1}{nK^{2}}\sum_{i,k}\mathbb{E}_{S,S^{\prime}}[\langle g_{k}^{(i)},W_{k\setminus i}^{(1,\tau)}-W_{k}^{(1,\tau)}\rangle] (19)
+1n​K2​∑i,k,j∑q=2R𝔼S,S′​[⟨gk(i),Vj(q)−Vj∖k,i(q)⟩]1𝑛superscript𝐾2subscript𝑖𝑘𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑞2𝑅subscript𝔼𝑆superscript𝑆′delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑗𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑗𝑘𝑖𝑞\displaystyle\>+\frac{1}{nK^{2}}\sum_{i,k,j}\sum_{q=2}^{R}\mathbb{E}_{S,S^{\prime}}\biggl{[}\biggl{\langle}g_{k}^{(i)},V_{j}^{(q)}-V_{{j\setminus k,i}}^{(q)}\biggr{\rangle}\biggr{]}

(20)

For fixed (k,j)∈[K]2𝑘𝑗superscriptdelimited-[]𝐾2(k,j)\in[K]^{2} and r∈[R]𝑟delimited-[]𝑅r\in[R], denote for q∈[2;R]𝑞2𝑅q\in[2;R], i∈Ir𝑖subscript𝐼𝑟i\in I_{r}, Cq,i≔𝔼S,S′​[⟨gk(i),Vj(q)−Vj∖k,i(q)⟩]≔subscript𝐶𝑞𝑖subscript𝔼𝑆superscript𝑆′delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑗𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑗𝑘𝑖𝑞C_{q,i}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{S,S^{\prime}}[\langle g_{k}^{(i)},V_{j}^{(q)}-V_{j\setminus k,i}^{(q)}\rangle] (notational dependence on (j,k,r)𝑗𝑘𝑟(j,k,r) is omitted for simplicity).   • (iii)

    The term ∑q=r+1R∑i∈IrCq,isuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑟1𝑅subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑟subscript𝐶𝑞𝑖\sum_{q=r+1}^{R}\sum_{i\in I_{r}}C_{q,i} is bounded by

    where br+1≔∑q=r+1R∑t=1τηq,t​(∏h=1t−11+L​ηq,h)≔subscript𝑏𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑟1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝜏subscript𝜂𝑞𝑡superscriptsubscriptproductℎ1𝑡11𝐿subscript𝜂𝑞ℎb_{r+1}\coloneqq\sum_{q=r+1}^{R}\sum_{t=1}^{\tau}\eta_{q,t}(\prod_{h=1}^{t-1}1+L\eta_{q,h}) and ∏h=101+L​ηq,h=1superscriptsubscriptproductℎ101𝐿subscript𝜂𝑞ℎ1\prod_{h=1}^{0}1+L\eta_{q,h}=1. Finally, using (19) and substituting using (20) and the above completes the proof of Theorem 1.

Appendix B Details of the experiments

Datasets

We conducted the simulations on datasets implemented in the open source Machine Learning library Scikit-Learn [24], which are “california_housing" and “friedman1". The results of our numerical experiments were consistent with both datasets; Figure 3 presents simulations using “friedman1" dataset.

Model & algorithm implementation

OLS and LocalSGD are implemented using SGDRegressor from Scikit-Learn and custom Python classes.

Training and hyperparameters

The models were trained for one epoch, to coincide with the theoretical setup of this paper. The learning rate was set to η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01.

Hardware and other resources

We performed our experiments on a machine equipped with 56 CPUs Intel Xeon E5-2690v4 2.60GHz. The experiments are conducted using Python language.
